metadata.titleEn: Data of plant DNA in surface sediments of 33 lakes in Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau and arid northwestern China
metadata.description: The data include raw sequencing result of plant DNA in surface sediments of 33 lakes in the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau and arid northwestern China. We used PowerMax Soil Kit of Qiagen company in Germany to extract DNA, then used universal plant primer g-h (Taberlet et et al., 2007) to amplify P6 loop of chloroplast trnL (UAA) intron in the sample. The PCR products were then sent to Fasteris company in Switzerland for the next-generation paired-end sequencing. The sequencing instrument is Illumina Nextseq 550. The data quality score (Q30) is 81.97.
metadata.instructions: The data is fastq file. It is recommended to use obitools and other bioinformatic tools to read and analyze the data. Please refer to https://datadryad.org/stash/dataset/doi :10.5061/dryad.k6djh9w4r.

literatureList.titleEn: Plant diversity in sedimentary DNA obtained from high-latitude (Siberia) and high-elevation lakes (China)
literatureList.referenceEn: Stoof-Leichsenring KR, Liu S, Jia W, Li K, Pestryakova LA, Mischke S, Cao X, Liu X, Ni J, Neuhaus S, Herzschuh U (2020) Plant diversity in sedimentary DNA obtained from high-latitude (Siberia) and high-elevation lakes (China). Biodiversity Data Journal 8: e57089. https://doi.org/10.3897/BDJ.8.e57089

literatureList.titleEn: Research on the modern processes of plant DNA in sediment from lakes in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau and the Northwest Arid Region.

background: Arctic and high-elevation ecosystems are very sensitive to natural and anthropogenically-induced climate variability. Anthropogenic warming and changes in land-use have been considered to shift vegetation composition and plant richness in these areas during the last centuries and decades. Modern plant sedDNA data, as a modern training-set, can be applied to reconstruct past vegetation types in alpine and arctic ecosystems, which in pollen-based reconstruction, can be largely biased due to the presence of poor modern pollen analogues. Since the last decade, plant sedDNA have been applied to lake surface-sediment samples to identify modern plant communities and to lake sediment cores to reconstruct local plant diversity changes in the past. Typically, plant sedDNA is retrieved by a metabarcoding approach that utilises the g/h primers that amplify a short fragment of the trnL P6 loop of the plant chloroplast genome. The P6 loop markers have been widely applied for the identification of plants in lake sediment samples and other environmental samples, such as soils, permafrost, and mock samples. For lake sediments, the use of P6 loop markers allows an identification of plants to a low taxonomic level and the recognition of more taxa from the local lake catchment. As plant diversity obtained from lakes' sedDNA reflects local plant communities, it is more suitable to reconstruct the past local plant diversity.
research objective: This study investigates modern plant diversity applying a plant-specific metabarcoding approach on sedimentary DNA of surface sediment samples from 262 lake localities covering a large geographical, climatic and ecological gradient.
challenges: There is a lack of understanding how environmental variability shaped local plant diversity in these remote areas. Until now, we have only a limited understanding of how environmental conditions influence the preservation of the plant sedDNA proxy which requires larger sedDNA datasets spanning a wide range of environmental conditions to be investigated.
methods: DNA extraction of surface sediment samples was carried out in the molecular genetic laboratories for environmental genetics at Alfred Wegener Institute Helmholtz Centre for Polar and Marine Research. We ran separate PCR set-ups for each of the extraction batches, including a PCR negative control (NTC). We produced at least two PCR replicates of each sample, which were set up on different days. The four pools were sequenced using the external sequencing service (Fasteris SA, Switzerland). We analysed in total 262 lake samples, resulting in 688 PCRs, which divide into 553 sample PCRs and 135 PCRs of extraction blanks and NTCs.
dataset: The underlying modern dataset is a large sampling set covering a wide range of environmental conditions, which will provide an openly accessible data resource which can be used to address the effect of the environment on the preservation of the sedDNA proxy.

Verification.Question: Is DNA extraction from surface sediment samples in this domain typically carried out using specialized kits?
Are P6 loop markers commonly used for identifying plant taxa in lake sediment samples?
Does the data collection approach include sequencing service from an external provider?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the DNA extraction for plant sedDNA datasets typically conducted using specialized soil kits, general DNA extraction kits, or other methods?

Concept Completion.Question: What challenges exist in understanding the preservation of plant sedDNA in various environmental conditions?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that ensures the preservation of plant sedimentary DNA in lake surface sediment samples?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method is the extraction of DNA from surface sediment samples using a PowerMax soil kit, followed by a plant-specific metabarcoding approach that targets the trnL P6 loop of the plant chloroplast genome. This method involves using g/h primers for PCR amplification and high-throughput sequencing to ensure preservation and accurate identification of plant sedDNA from local lake catchments.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge in creating a dataset spanning a wide range of environmental conditions for investigating environmental impacts on sedDNA preservation?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the limited understanding of how environmental variability affects local plant diversity and the preservation of the plant sedDNA proxy. This requires collecting and analyzing large sedDNA datasets from diverse environmental conditions, which is essential to address how these conditions influence sedDNA preservation.

Example.Question: Provide an example of a research approach used to investigate modern plant diversity in remote lake areas using sedimentary DNA.
Example.Answer: A research approach involves applying a plant-specific metabarcoding method on sedimentary DNA from surface sediment samples across 262 lake localities. This method utilizes PCR amplification with g/h primers and high-throughput sequencing to analyze plant diversity, offering insights into how environmental conditions shape local plant communities.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the DNA extraction methods used in sedimentary plant DNA data collection?
Feature Specification.Answer: PowerMax soil kit by Qiagen, molecular genetic laboratories, separate PCR set-ups for each extraction batch, PCR negative controls (NTC), at least two PCR replicates of each sample on different days.

Feature Specification.Question: What specific attributes of plant metabarcoding are utilized in the analysis of sedimentary DNA from lake samples?
Feature Specification.Answer: universal plant primers g-h, trnL P6 loop of the chloroplast genome, identification of plants to a low taxonomic level, recognition of more taxa from the local lake catchment

Definition.Question: What is a 'metabarcoding approach' in the context of sedimentary DNA analysis?
Definition.Answer: A metabarcoding approach in sedimentary DNA analysis refers to a method that utilizes specific primers, such as the g/h primers, to amplify a short fragment of the trnL P6 loop of the plant chloroplast genome. This approach allows for the identification of plants in lake sediment samples and other environmental samples by targeting specific DNA regions, facilitating the reconstruction of past vegetation types.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'P6 loop markers' in plant DNA analysis?
Definition.Answer: P6 loop markers refer to specific DNA sequences within the trnL (UAA) intron region of the chloroplast genome that are targeted in plant DNA analysis. These markers are widely used for the identification of plants in lake sediment samples due to their ability to identify plants at a low taxonomic level and recognize more taxa from the local lake catchment.

Comparison.Question: How do the DNA extraction methods used in the Qiagen PowerMax soil kit compare to those used in molecular genetic laboratories, such as the Alfred Wegener Institute, in terms of efficiency and reliability for plant sedDNA analysis?
Comparison.Answer: The Qiagen PowerMax soil kit is utilized for extracting DNA in the dataset related to Tibetan Plateau and Northwest Arid Region lakes, whereas the molecular genetic laboratories at Alfred Wegener Institute perform DNA extraction with separate PCR setups and multiple PCR replicates for reliability. Both methods share a focus on ensuring the quality and integrity of DNA samples, but the latter emphasizes controlled experimental setups and replication.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the range of environmental conditions covered by the plant sedDNA datasets used in studies on the Tibetan Plateau and Northwest Arid Region compared to those covering 262 lake localities in a large geographical gradient?
Comparison.Answer: The dataset from the Tibetan Plateau and Northwest Arid Region covers 33 lakes with a focus on local plant diversity, whereas the study involving 262 lake localities spans a large geographical, climatic, and ecological gradient. This broader dataset aims to investigate the effect of environmental conditions on sedDNA preservation, offering a wider range of environmental variability compared to the more localized dataset.

Interpretation.Question: How might variations in geographic, climatic, and ecological conditions influence the integrity and preservation of plant sedDNA in sediment samples?
Interpretation.Answer: The preservation of plant sedDNA in sediment samples is influenced by environmental conditions, which is not fully understood. Larger sedDNA datasets spanning a wide range of environmental conditions are needed to investigate how these factors affect the preservation of the sedDNA proxy.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when using metabarcoding approaches to identify plant communities in lake sediment samples across diverse environmental settings?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include understanding how environmental variability affects local plant diversity in remote areas and the influence of environmental conditions on the preservation of the plant sedDNA proxy, which necessitates larger sedDNA datasets for thorough investigation.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can modern plant diversity data obtained from lake sedimentary DNA be leveraged to enhance our understanding of past vegetation changes in alpine and arctic ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Modern plant sedDNA data can be applied to reconstruct past vegetation types in alpine and arctic ecosystems, offering a modern training-set that counterbalances the biases in pollen-based reconstructions due to poor modern pollen analogues. This facilitates a more accurate recognition of local plant communities and past local plant diversity.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes contribute to the variability in plant diversity data retrieved from sedimentary DNA in high-elevation and arctic ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Arctic and high-elevation ecosystems are very sensitive to natural and anthropogenically-induced climate variability, which can shift vegetation composition and plant richness in these areas. The environmental conditions influence the preservation of the plant sedDNA proxy, highlighting a need for larger sedDNA datasets spanning a wide range of environmental conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to understand the impact of environmental variability on local plant diversity through sedimentary DNA analysis?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: There is a lack of understanding of how environmental variability shaped local plant diversity in remote areas. The limited understanding of how environmental conditions influence the preservation of the plant sedDNA proxy requires larger sedDNA datasets covering a wide range of environmental conditions to be investigated.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of applying a plant-specific metabarcoding approach on sedimentary DNA for understanding modern plant diversity in extreme environments?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying a plant-specific metabarcoding approach on sedimentary DNA can lead to a better understanding of modern plant diversity in extreme environments as it provides a modern training-set for reconstructing past vegetation types. It allows identification of plants to a low taxonomic level and recognition of more taxa from local lake catchments, which is beneficial in reconstructing past local plant diversity.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the repercussions of limited understanding of environmental conditions on the preservation of the plant sedDNA proxy?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The limited understanding of environmental conditions on the preservation of the plant sedDNA proxy may hinder the accurate assessment of how environmental variability shapes local plant diversity. A larger sedDNA dataset spanning various environmental conditions is needed to better understand this effect, which could impact the reliability of plant diversity reconstructions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How could the lack of comprehensive sedDNA datasets across diverse environmental contexts affect research into local plant diversity changes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The lack of comprehensive sedDNA datasets across diverse environmental contexts could limit the ability to assess how environmental variability influences local plant diversity. It may restrict the exploration of how different environmental conditions affect the preservation and reliability of the plant sedDNA proxy, posing challenges in understanding past biodiversity changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of applying a plant-specific metabarcoding approach to sedimentary DNA in surface sediment samples from lake localities?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to investigate modern plant diversity across a large geographical, climatic, and ecological gradient, providing insights into local plant communities which can be used to reconstruct past vegetation types in alpine and arctic ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to create a large modern dataset covering a wide range of environmental conditions for sedimentary DNA research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Creating such a dataset is important to address the effect of environmental conditions on the preservation of the sedDNA proxy, as there is currently limited understanding of how these conditions influence the preservation of plant sedDNA in remote areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intention behind using the g-h primers to amplify the trnL P6 loop of the plant chloroplast genome in sediment samples?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to enable the identification of plants to a low taxonomic level and recognize more taxa from the local lake catchment, as this marker has been widely applied in lake sediment samples and other environmental samples for identifying plants.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to extract and sequence plant DNA from lake surface sediments in high-altitude or arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: DNA is extracted from lake surface sediments using the Qiagen PowerMax soil kit. The plant DNA is then amplified with the g-h primers targeting the trnL P6 loop and sequenced using Illumina NextSeq 550 at Fasteris SA, Switzerland.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the accurate extraction and sequencing of plant DNA from lake sediment samples?
Enablement.Answer: The use of the PowerMax soil kit from Qiagen for DNA extraction, along with the application of universal plant primers g-h for PCR amplification, and the high-throughput sequencing capabilities of the Illumina NextSeq 550, enable the accurate extraction and sequencing of plant DNA from lake sediment samples.

Enablement.Question: How do variations in environmental conditions impact the preservation and detection of plant sedimentary DNA in alpine and arctic lake samples?
Enablement.Answer: Environmental conditions influence the preservation of plant sedDNA proxies, necessitating larger datasets spanning a wide range of conditions to understand their impact on sedDNA detection in remote alpine and arctic regions.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does a large and diverse sampling set enhance the understanding of environmental influences on sedimentary DNA proxies?
Enablement.Answer: A large sampling set covering a wide range of environmental conditions provides an openly accessible data resource to address the effects of the environment on the preservation of the sedDNA proxy, enhancing the understanding of these influences.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in understanding how environmental variability influences the preservation of plant sedDNA proxies in surface sediment samples?
Expectation.Answer: There is a lack of understanding of how environmental variability shaped local plant diversity in these remote areas, and the preservation of plant sedDNA proxies requires larger sedDNA datasets spanning a wide range of environmental conditions to be investigated.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected reasons for using a large sampling set covering diverse environmental conditions to study modern plant diversity using plant-specific metabarcoding approaches?
Expectation.Answer: A large sampling set covering a wide range of environmental conditions is expected to provide an openly accessible data resource, which can be used to address the effect of the environment on the preservation of the sedDNA proxy.

Expectation.Question: Why is it essential to conduct separate PCR set-ups for each of the extraction batches, including a PCR negative control, when analyzing sedDNA from surface sediment samples?
Expectation.Answer: Separate PCR set-ups for each of the extraction batches, including a PCR negative control, are essential to ensure methodological rigor and to account for potential contamination, which is crucial when analyzing sedDNA from surface sediment samples.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using plant-specific metabarcoding approaches in identifying modern plant diversity in sedimentary environments?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness of using plant-specific metabarcoding approaches, such as those utilizing the g/h primers for amplifying the trnL P6 loop, is significant as it allows for the identification of plants to a low taxonomic level and recognizes more taxa from the local lake catchment. This method has been widely applied in lake sediments and other environmental samples, providing a robust tool for reconstructing past local plant diversity.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges do you see in understanding the influence of environmental variability on the preservation of sedimentary plant DNA, and how might these challenges be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: One challenge in understanding the influence of environmental variability on the preservation of sedimentary plant DNA is the lack of comprehensive datasets that span a wide range of environmental conditions. Addressing this challenge requires larger datasets that can provide insights into how different conditions affect the preservation of the sedDNA proxy, which will help in better interpreting the historical biodiversity data.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how valuable is the contribution of large, openly accessible datasets in advancing research on the effects of environmental conditions on sedimentary DNA preservation?
Judgmental.Answer: The contribution of large, openly accessible datasets is highly valuable as these resources enable researchers to address questions regarding the effects of environmental conditions on sedimentary DNA preservation. Such datasets help in building a broader understanding of how environmental variability shapes local plant diversity, offering a foundation for more accurate reconstructions of past ecosystems.

Assertion.Question: I can't understand how the use of the g/h primers enhances the identification of plant species in sediment samples.
Assertion.Answer: Typically, plant sedDNA is retrieved by a metabarcoding approach that utilises the g/h primers which amplify a short fragment of the trnL P6 loop of the plant chloroplast genome. The P6 loop markers have been widely applied for the identification of plants in lake sediment samples and allow an identification of plants to a low taxonomic level and the recognition of more taxa from the local lake catchment.

Assertion.Question: I am unsure about the challenges faced in understanding how environmental conditions affect the preservation of plant sedDNA.
Assertion.Answer: There is a lack of understanding how environmental variability shaped local plant diversity in these remote areas. Until now, we have only a limited understanding of how environmental conditions influence the preservation of the plant sedDNA proxy which requires larger sedDNA datasets spanning a wide range of environmental conditions to be investigated.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the importance of having a dataset covering a wide range of environmental conditions for studying plant diversity in lake sediments.
Assertion.Answer: The underlying modern dataset is a large sampling set covering a wide range of environmental conditions, which will provide an openly accessible data resource that can be used to address the effect of the environment on the preservation of the sedDNA proxy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges associated with using plant sedDNA to reconstruct past vegetation types and suggest methodological strategies to overcome these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: One challenge is the limited understanding of how environmental conditions influence the preservation of sedDNA. Methodological strategies could include expanding the dataset to cover a wider range of environmental conditions and conducting comparative studies to identify factors that may aid in the preservation of DNA in sediment samples.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose a comprehensive research approach for assessing how environmental variability impacts local plant diversity using sedDNA across multiple lake localities.
Request/Directive.Answer: A comprehensive research approach could include collecting sediment samples from a large number of lake localities across different geographical and climatic regions, using standardized DNA extraction and sequencing protocols, and analyzing the results to correlate environmental variables with plant diversity as reflected in sedDNA.
